review_title: Come for the Mission, Stay for the Culture, Leave for More Pay
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: The warm, welcoming culture at Whitman-Walker Health is hard to beat. This organization prioritizes its patients and the mental health of its staff, so it's easy to be happy here.
cons: There are no merit-based raises, which the organization usually justifies with respectable cost of living salary increases. Unfortunately that increase was wiped out due to COVID, along with staff education benefits. No word on if that will ever come back.

pros: Affirming, innovative, great benefits, LGBTQ competent
cons: Below market salaries, difficult work/life balance

pros: Supportive and mission driven, great work/life balance
cons: Non competitive pay, but that is par for the course with non profits

review_title: Whitman Walker Clinic, a continued downward spiral.
pros: WWC is a community health center that serves the needs of GLBT, underserved, and HIV+ people in DC. The work done here is crucial to the health and well-being of its client base. The professionals that work at WWC are some of the best in their field, not because they are highly compensated, but because they truly care about this work and helping people.
cons: The clinic has been terribly mis-managed for years. The mis-management continues to this day in that day-to-day management is chaotic at best and incompetent at times. Management has no credibility that they can competently lead the organization out of its financial crisis. Each year there are layoffs and assertions made that the organization is on the right track. More layoffs and financial disasters then follow. First the organization fired managers because there were not enough direct service workers and salaries were reallocated. Then they fired line workers because they were incompetent. Then they fired management because they didn't want to cut direct services and blamed it on the poor economy, when in fact they were seeing an increase in client visits. The real problem is that the financial management of the clinic has been so poor that they are not competent to access the funding sources which are available and that visits which are billable to insurance or grants are not billed and hence the clinic ends up loosing money because of its own managerial incompetence.

job_title: Behavioral Health Services (BHS) in Washington, DC
pros:
Supportive leadership and management. 
Feeling empowered by a compassionate team united by a common mission.
cons: As the company grows, it can be hard to get to know people in different departments.

review_title: Great benefits+work/life balance, OK salary, OK management
pros: The benefits are great here, and I have better insurance/vacation time than many other comparable positions. The salary is competitive for the nonprofit sector in DC. The pace can be pretty fast at times, given the busy nature of the clinic. The work/life balance is outstanding--the work doesn't really follow you home or require you to stay too late too often.
cons: There's a lot of human error involved in various cross-department communication. There are also wildly different standards of professionalism in the departments. The patients can be both great and incredibly difficult to deal with.

review_title: They use 'Whitman-Walker Family' to reel you in
pros: Extremely socially inclusive (LGBTQ Friendly, open to many family types),  Laid back dress code (department dependent),  Encouragement to be yourself and open with co-workers. Friendly work environment
cons: Little to no opportunity for growth from within in terms of promotion. Lackluster and disorganized managers (department dependent). No reason to improve past initial 90 days. Most positions have forced union contributions. No real direction from managers or unrealistic expectations. Horrible communication between departments.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Washington, DC
pros: Management cares about you. benefits are far above most local non profit health centers in the area. Great advancement structure. Competitive pay.
cons: Stressful work environment. In this type of work, it is hard to disconnect when you go home.

job_title: Nurse Case Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Friendly, engaged.  Staff and management all very supportive.
cons: No real cons! If it weren't for school, I would go back.
